Sound production: In the openings? Impeccable! In the anime itself? Nothing much different, it has good ost's but nothing that is as epic or differential as the previous parts.\n
Characters: Well, here it is worth noting that my note is above what I expected from the anime myself, and the culprit of this is the character Yoshikage Kira, one of the most worked villains I have ever seen in the shounens, something worth mentioning. The anime's preoccupation with putting other characters as narrative masters is always brilliant in Jojo's, it makes us closer to the character.\n
Josuke may not be the best character in the anime, but he's still a good character with a kinder soul, which reminds us of Jonathan Joestar.\n
Several characters gain prominence in the work, and have their moments as owners of the narrative.\n
Enjoyment and Overall: Well, I admit that this part may not be the most attractive, at first really it seems that nothing will happen great, but from the moment Kira is inserted into the work as a villain, the narrative accelerates!\n
Diamond Wa Kudakenai is one of the best parts of Jojo's, incredibly able to make a villain more built than the greatest villainous icon of the Work: Dio Brando. Yes, Kira manages to be a better villain than him in technical matters.\n
Diamond features dramatic moments, moments of tension and extreme distress, which puts the viewer's mind to work.\n
I do not recommend that you watch without first watching the previous ones, because it's very worth seeing the whole connection between the characters!\n
A good work, with a good ending and good characters!

The JoJo franchise has long appealed to those who are appreciative of fashionable character designs, attractive visuals, over the top action with a dash of absurdist comedy. Diamond is Unbreakable takes that formula, adds a Slice of Life mystery to the equation, throws it all in a blender and turns the dial on high speed. It took people some time to adjust to the new flavor, but the result was arguably the best JoJo has ever been.
Unlike previous seasons this story takes place in a single location - the town of Morioh where stand users are popping up for unknown reasons and an outbreak ofmurders have become rampant. This town is an incredibly fun environment where every corner of the street has a unique story to tell and each character has an odd quirk that defines them in a memorable way. If not the best character cast, it is certainly the most robust headlined by three generations of Joestar decedents and and the infamous Kira Yoshikage.


As per usual in this franchise, art is a strong point. This anime makes up for not having a ton of fluid animation scenes by creating a beautiful aesthetic that is appealing to the eye. The colors leap out of the screen almost telling the story itself, and the attractive character designs make them all very easy to identify.


This is JoJo at its finest, told in way never seen before in the franchise, and in a manner that is easier for more people to enjoy than just it's former target audience.

"I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winningand losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone."



From this very quote I could tell the brilliance in character that makes Diamond is Unbreakable a fantastic continuation from Jojo. Even after finishing the series a year ago, I still very bizarrely remember this same monologue given by one of the characters. It has left such a mark on me that I will surely always remember this series for what it is. The story takes place in a city known as Morioh, where our character Josuke lives his regular high-school life until a series of murders occur in his quiet town. The setting is typical and the premise is nothing special, but that's not what makes this diamond shine bright...


Aside from the very vibrant color palette that very nicely characterizes the bright nature of the city of Morioh making it feel alive, and aside from the phenomenal OST that brilliantly captures the essence of several characters, and aside from the genius stand inventions that you will see across this series (which, for the record, is leagues better than Stardust Crusaders), it's the characters that really stood out to me.


In comes our antagonist. A man who leads a casual life that goes to work, enjoys his day, comes home, relaxes, and then sleeps at a regular and coordinated schedule. Completely normal. Yet, that's what makes this character so brilliant. He's the definition of normalcy and all he wants is to live his own quiet life - until he experiences intruders in his personal lifestyle. Time after time, it is a relentless struggle of him trying to avoid these new intruders - what do they want and why are they intruding? Naturally, if you wanted to live a quiet life like this, you'd be annoyed when someone interrupts it, no?


And here lies the issue with our antagonist. His perception of reality is completely average and mediocre and he fails to understand why anybody would ruin his normal life. He wants to avoid trouble at all costs. The antagonist is a walking paradox of trying to live a quiet life, but also does anything to obtain this mean - an inherent contradiction in introducing noise in his calm and typical lifestyle. His drive to continue living this way pushes him to extremes, and even near the end of the series, I found it so disgustingly human in how he pushes himself to the absolute limits to prevent anyone from shattering this ideal. 


Never have I seen such a character that has captured the essence of "what is human" in being an antagonist; minus a certain deviation which would be a spoiler, if revealed. His paradoxical nature and the absolute trait of being a mediocre civilian makes it sheer brilliance. Villains don't have to be extravagant, they don't have to have a corrupt wish to bring destruction to the universe, nor do they need to exist for the sole reason of stopping the protagonist. Sometimes, villains are completely normal people too, and this concept was masterfully executed in Diamond is Unbreakable.

Jojo's Bizarre Adventure part four Diamond is Unbreakable is arguably one of the most beloved and well-known works of Hirihiko Araki. 
Story: 10
Diamond is Unbreakable, follows the daily lives of the people of the small Japanese town of Morioh. Despite being relatively peaceful, it has the highest death to population ratio in all of Japan. In order to figure out why this phenomenon has occurred in such an insignificant town, the young marine biologist and all-around badass Jotaro Kujo set off to investigate. On his journey, Jotaro enlists the help of his highschooler uncle Josuke Higashikata, Koichi Hirose a young student, the bad-tempered Okuyasu Nijimura,and Rohan Kishibe the famous manga artist. The story shows us the lives of these young men as they experience friendship and hardship discovering the dark secrets of Morioh.


Art: 10

The bright, colorful, and fluid art style used in this adaptation perfectly expresses the kind of art that Araki uses in the manga. Everything blends very well, and the animation is quite impressive. The character designs are arguably just as good if not better than their manga counterpart is in my opinion. My only complaint would be the outsourcing for backgrounds and animation that David Productions did in many instances. It is, however, understandable and a great budget saver for such a long highly expensive series.


Sound: 9

I don't really have much to say about the sound other than the fact that it has some of the best intros in anime, and that the outro is "I Want You!" by Savage Garden. Not only do the intros have amazing music, but they are also accompanied by subtle details pertaining to the story. In a way, all of the intros together tell a story. Do I even need to say anything else about the outro?


Characters: 9

The main characters were funny, relatable, and their dynamic just works. The plot was compelling, and the episodic villains were so well written despite their short screen times. The main Jojo of the season, Josuke Higashikata, is the illegitimate child of Jotaro's grandfather Joseph Joestar. He has a short fuse, is manipulative at times, but he also has a kind heart and passion for helping others. Alongside him is Koichi Hirose, a young boy breaming with willpower and kindness. He is incredibly perceptive, and quick on his feet in tough situations. Okuyasu Nijimura is Josuke's best friend. He's a punk teenager with an attitude and big heart. He has an even worse temper than Josuke and isn't very bright, but what he lacks in intelligence he makes up for in resolve and determination. And of course, we can't forget, Rohan Kishibe, a famous manga artist who decides to help Jotaro in order to gain inspiration for his manga writing. I wouldn't call Rohan a "hero" for helping Jotaro and friends; I'd say he's more of a curious cookie who does good along the way. Now, that doesn't mean he isn't a fantastic character because he is in my eyes, but I suppose that's up for whoever is reading this to decide.


(SPOILER WARNING)


Kira Yoshikage, the main villain of part four, is by far my favorite villain of all time, and as of right now is my favorite character in all of Jojo and anime for that matter. He is a psychopathic murderer who has a creepy hand fetish and some really strange nails to boot. Although I do have to hand it to him (hehe hand), he is incredibly smart and rather clever, he also has some ridiculously bs luck that only makes him more interesting. 


Enjoyment: 10

Honestly, part four of Jojo one of the most enjoyable and creative shows I've ever seen. I feel like most people who watch this will enjoy it, whether or not they like battle shounen anime or anime in general. This is probably due to its well-executed story, its relatable and strongly motivated characters, its compelling villains, and the seamlessly never-ending music references. And of course, I can't forget the crux of the series stands! Stands. are in my opinion, the most creative and cool ways to have otherworldly powers with individually specific and abilities. I've rewatched many of the fight scenes, and the innovative ways in which the protagonists defeat the enemies and their stands, still fascinate me to this day. That isn't part four specific either. Stand battles, be it part three or even part eight, are so bizarre (hehe bizarre) and they really make you think sometimes about how the protagonists are gonna get out of this one. 


Overall, I'd say Jojo's is one of my favorite anime/manga series, if not my favorite, and I highly recommend you check it out. Besides, my stand, Hypnotized, has the ability to make anyone who reads this review instantly begin watching Jojo. If you try to resist, it will reverberate WRRRYY! in your head constantly, and this thing has an A in vitality so it won't be going away anytime soon. It's also an automatic type stand, so I can't turn it off either. Good luck!

Diamond is Unbreakable (hence DIU) is another TV series in the JoJo's Bizarre Adventure franchise, adapting part 4 of the original manga. Generally speaking, it is a good fighting shounen that keeps some fundamental elements of its predeccesors and also brings many new things to the table.
Before writing anything else, I would like to point out that while each part of JoJo may be viewed independently from others, it is much better to watch them in chronological order, as you may lose some important context otherwise. So, if you haven't watched anything from JoJo yet, I highly recommend to start with the first TV series.
STORY
Eachpart of JoJo follows the members of Joestar family at different time periods, and each of the already released series makes some shift in the formula. Since DIU is not the 1st series in the franchise, I guess it makes sense to draw some comparisons in order to put things into perspective.


I. Unlike the first series and both parts of Stardust Crusaders (hence SC), which have a strong adventure element with the characters travelling around the world, DIU takes place entirely in one town and its surroundings. However, even though the show has a relatively small slice-of-life setting, it doesn't prevent it from being interesting or entertaining in any way, as it has a good pacing and keeps introducing new characters, powers and stories which often take place in different locations of the town.


II. Speaking of those stories and plot continuity in general, DIU has a more continuous plot than SC. Whereas the latter has an entirely stand-of-the-week plot where events in different episodes have little influence on each other and the final outcome, this series has short story arcs where events are more directly related to each other. The fundamental similarity between the two series is that both of them are essentially about introducing many characters with interesting powers, putting them against each other and tying all those battles together. However, DIU does a better job at this because of a better plot structure.


III. Speaking of the powers, the characters use stands, which follows the change that happened in Stardust Crusaders. I actually like hamon/ripple from the first series a lot, because it adds an element of training to the plot, and because it's somewhat akin to using qi in Chinese martial arts. That being said, the concept of stands also has its notable strengths, as it offers a lot more variety than hamon and always keeps the viewer interested with new powers and strategies introduced.

Overall, whether you prefer hamon, or stands, or like them equally is a matter of personal taste more than anything.


IV. While stands in SC are named after tarot cards and Egyptian gods, DIU returns to the practice of referencing Western rock bands that already existed in the first series: as you probably remember, it has a character named after AC/DC, and two characters named Dire and Straits, which is a reference to Dire Straits. This series, however, goes further than its predecessor and has more of these references. For example:

- the name of the main antagonist's stand is Killer Queen, which is a reference to a famous Queen song (and one of that stand's abilities is named after another famous song by Queen);

- one of the characters has a stand named Red Hot Chili Pepper, which is a reference to Red Hot Chili Peppers;

- another character has a stand named Highway Star, which is a reference to a famous Deep Purple song;

- and even the name of the protagonist's stand, Crazy Diamond, is an obvious reference to a Pink Floyd song called Shine on You Crazy Diamond.

Besides the rock references, the series occasionally refers to old-school manga and some famous people of that era: for example, they mention the name of some famous wrestler in one of the episodes, which is used as a pun.

Overall, this aspect is one of the things that I've always liked about JoJo, because it adds an interesting and unique flavour to the series, and also because I'm a rock/blues/metal guy myself, and I like many of those old-school bands very much.


Now, when I mentioned some specifics of the story, let's talk about the controversial aspects it has.


1) Just like other JoJo anime, DIU is very heavy on explanations and expository monologue, which is both good and bad:

- on the one hand, while the series constantly introduces new unusual elements to the plot (new stand powers, ghosts, aliens etc.), it also does a great job at setting the rules of how those elements work most of the time. This is something that I've always liked about JoJo and one of the things that makes this series good: no matter what crazy ideas the author comes up with, he usually gives some basic explanation and sets some limitations to the way they work, which makes the whole thing look a little less arbitrary, and also makes the characters use interesting strategies, which are undoubtedly one of the main strengths that all JoJo anime have;

- at the same time, the constant talking also leads to some fairly ridiculous situations. For example, one character gets attacked by the antagonist who stands several meters from him, and the attacked character and his friend somehow manage to exchange several phrases in those few seconds before the blow is landed, as if their dialogue exists in a different timeframe. Or, there is a situation when the antagonist talks to an almost defeated character, says that he has twenty seconds (!) before that character's friends arrive... and yet he doesn't hurry to leave the scene at all, keeps talking and gets beaten in the end.

Besides, this show is one of the biggest infringements of the "show, don't tell" rule I've ever seen, as the characters often comment on bloody obvious things that need no commentary at all. For example, the characters chase the antagonist, he disappears in the crowd, and one of them screams something like: "PEOPLE ARE GOING FROM WORK! HE DISAPPEARED IN THE CROWDS!". Well, thank you Captain Obvious: you've just ruined a dramatic moment by explaining something I totally couldn't see myself. And this thing happens quite often and, of course, detracts some points from the enjoyment.


2) While most arcs of the show are very short and often limited to one or two episodes, there is a long arc involving a serial killer, who is also the user of a very powerful stand. This arc is more interesting because it has elements of a thriller and many lives at stake, which makes it feel more important than all other arcs. The problem here is that the show that loves to explain virtually everything that happens on screen (including many things that need no explanation at all) somehow drops the ball in this arc and doesn't address a number of important issues that need to be addressed. Those issues are spoilers for the most part, so I'll try to talk about them as vaguely as possible. However, if you absolutely want to avoid getting spoiled, skip the next section of the review:

SPOILERS

- one of the characters introduced in this arc is an eleven-year-old kid who spies on his parents using hidden cameras installed all around their house and a monitor in his room, and this plays a very important role in the plot. The problem is that the show never explains where this kid got the equipment and how he was able to install, use and maintain it. Even if we assume that he is a young genius who somehow developed rather specific technical skills at his age that even many adults don't have, it still doesn't explain where and how he got all that equipment in the first place;

- the antagonist very conveniently reveals himself by loudly pronouncing his name twice in a situation where he absolutely doesn't have to do it;

- in the fight that follows, the antagonist fights against two characters, while the other three stand just round the corner. The kid, who is also present at the scene, simply has to call for their help, and yet he doesn't do that even though he knows that those three characters stand there, and nothing prevents him from calling them;

- after one of the characters explodes because of touching another character's body with the antagonist's bomb planted in it, Jousuke saves that character by restoring his body with Crazy Diamond's ability, even though all parts of that character's body including his head were already torn in little pieces, and thus he was certainly already dead (and Jousuke's stand can't resurrect the dead, as was explained in the beginning of the series).

SPOILERS END

Overall, I think the story is still fine as it is, because it's well-paced, entertaining, and has a satisfying and conclusive ending.

That being said, it could have been even better if the show didn't constantly talk about obvious things and instead addressed some aspects that needed an actual explanation.


ANIMATION

First thing you will notice when watching this series is that it has some crazy colour schemes that change all the time. For example, you may see an orange sky which suddenly turns pink, or a character with grey hair which may turn blond or blue depending on the scene. This is probably a matter of a personal taste more than anything, but I personally like this feature: it is artistic, unusual and fits the general bizarrity of the series. Besides, it reminds me a lot of pop-art and those portraits by Andy Warhol where he depicted famous people like Che Guevara and Marilyn Monroe using different colours. In other words, this aspect of JoJo's animation may be considered another interesting tribute to Western culture and something that makes this show stand out of the crowd.

Besides, the series is marked with important change in character designs. While most characters in previous JoJo series are huge ripped men akin to those in Fist of the North Star, the proportions of characters in this series are basically those of normal people. That being said, the character designs still look very stylish, as they usually have interesting haircuts and fashion accessories, which makes them different from designs in many other anime.

The fighting scenes are also well-animated, and the battles often feature good shots and close-ups that add a lot to the dramatic effect.

In general, the art and animation are quite impressive in their own way, being some of the most memorable aspects this series has.


SOUND

DIU continues the tradition established in previous series by choosing a famous song in English for the ending credits. This time, it's a very good and very catchy song called I Want You by Australian duo Savage Garden. It's interesting to note that all ending songs in English which have been used so far in JoJo TV series appear in chronological progression:

- the first series has Roundabout - a 70s song by Yes;

- SC has Walk Like an Egyptian - an 80s hit by The Bangles;

- and this series has a 90s song by Savage Garden.

So, not only it is a great music choice and another tribute to Western culture, but that time progression is also an interesting feature which I haven't seen in any other anime franchise to this day. 

As for the opening songs and BGM, they are all very nice, energetic and fitting for the series, but not quite as catchy and memorable as the ending song. In fact, I can't even remember any background melody that particularly stood out for me, but on the other hand, they all do a great job at supporting the mood of the show.

Speaking of voice-acting, it's generally very good, with characters pronouncing various funny catchphrases, like Jousuke's "Greato!", Joutarou's "Yare Yare Daze" and, of course, Joseph's "OH MY GOD!!!". That being said, I really wish the characters didn't YELL all the time. I understand that YELLING is an integral part of JoJo that shows the passion and spirit of the characters, but sometimes it just sounds overly dramatic and really unnecessary, like in that scene with the antagonist disappearing in the crowds I mentioned earlier. Not saying it's a huge problem - just something the series could have improved on, in my opinion.


CHARACTERS

Just like the character designs, the cast also went through certain changes. While the protagonists in previous series were all ripped, GAR men, the protagonist of this series, Jousuke Higashikata, is an illegitimate son of Joseph Joestar and seemingly normal high schooler. However, while Jousuke looks like a normal guy of his age, he is by no means a generic character - rather, he is a smart, very reliable and kind guy (except when someone bad-mouths his haircut, that is), and I personally like him quite a lot.

His two best friends are Okuyasu, who is strong, not very clever and somewhat of a delinquent, and Kouichi - a short and seemingly timid guy who often overcomes his fear and becomes very brave in dangerous situations. They both are ok characters, but perhaps less charismatic than the companions of Jojos in previous series.

The anime also features the comeback of now older Joutarou Kuujou, who is easily one of the best, if not the best character in the series. He always talks sense and does reasonable things, and often acts like Jousuke's older brother and mentor despite being technically his nephew.

The other comeback character is Joseph Joestar himself, who is now an almost eighty-year-old man. He comes to Morioh in order to use his stand ability for finding other stand users. Sadly (and strangely), he never actually does that, and generally performs few memorable actions aside from some interesting father-son interactions with Jousuke and one truly heroic moment I won't spoil here.

The other memorable stand users are serial killer Kira Yoshikage and mangaka Kishibe Rohan. Rohan is one of my favourite characters in the show, as he eventually appears to be a much better guy than he seems at first: he actually cares about other people despite being a selfish bastard on the surface; his words may sound cynical, but they always make sense; and his fanatic, almost maniacal dedication to his work is actually admirable in its own way. As for Kira, he turns out to be a very good opponent for the main characters because of how ruthless and calculative he is.

The other stand users are far less likeable and interesting, in my opinion, like that yandere girl (whose only memorable trait is that she is a yandere), that greedy little guy Shingekiyo (who is fairly annoying and looks as if he belongs to Dragonball or some fantasy anime), Kira's father (who is fairly annoying and serves more as a plot device to create new stand users) and Toshikazu (who is frankly pathetic and has no interesting and respectable traits whatsoever). Perhaps, the only other stand user whom I genuinely like is Tonio the chef, but he plays a very small role in the series. 

Besides the stand users, there are regular humans (like the stand users' family members, for example) and two characters who are neither stand users nor regular humans. I won't spoil who they are, but let's just say that both of them are quite likeable, and each plays an important part in the plot.

Overall, the cast may be somewhat of a mixed bag, but it's still good, and I liked a number of characters in this series.


OVERALL

Like most, this anime has its visible drawbacks and could be surely improved in some areas. That being said, it's still a good, enjoyable and memorable series which is far better than most other shounens and most recent stuff in general. 

So, if you have already watched the previous JoJo series, I highly recommend to watch this one too. And if you haven't, go watch those first and enjoy the ride!

By far the best JoJo anime, it does things differently than the other 3 first parts, it has the best characters, and the highest overall episode quality, and here comes why.
Topic Number One!
Story 
Unlike the other parts, instead of focusing on a linear storyline, it focuses in little stories about the characters that introduces new characters and some plotpoints, or just show the characters doing cool stuff. This works really well for part 4 considering that the episodes have good premises, and set the tone of the anime pretty well, even thought it feels that some stuff could have gotten more attention, it doesn't reallysubtract from the experience.


Topic Zwei


Art


Part 4 has a different artstyle than the previous ones, being kinda of a transition from the party of immense and extremely masculine men, to something that's slightly more realistic.

And that's a change for the best, the character designs look better, and no longer look so ridiculous, however the animation budget is obviously extremely inferior to the other part, having many scenes that look weird, and various imperfections along the anime, although fortunely the blu-ray version fixed most of the animation errors.



Topic ACT THREE


Sound


As any JoJo part, it has a insanely good sound design(good enough that everyone makes memes with them), every time a character appears with their stand it just has the best sound effect ever for it, every punch, every ability activation, the sound effects fir perfectly.

Also the voice acting leaves nothing to complain, the characters have good voices, and they interpret their roles perfectly, making the quotes all the more memorable.

And the soundtrack as any JoJo part is solid gold, the openings kick ass, the musics fit and are also damn good on their own, the ending seems boring at first, but then you find that you can't stop listening to it. in my opinion it's the best soundtrack and sound design in all the JoJo series.


Topic For


Character


Part 4 features the best characters in the JoJo anime series(perhaps not better than part 5,but that's yet to be seen), everyone has their own cool personality and design, and their own cool power, no one aside from the extras characters feels bland.

And the villain is on par with the villains of the other JoJo parts, he manages to be believable even thought he doesn't has any specific motivation, which is something that's rare to see.


Top Five


Enjoyment


It's the most enjoyable part of JoJo, every episode is engaging, even the ones that don't contribute in anyway to the story. Morioh feels just like the Crazy small town that it's supposed to be, and you will not end up bored for even a second. the pacing is perfect and the direction is gold. making up for a golden experience.


Overall


The best part of JoJo, it blends everything that it has to make the most fun JoJo part. it's the peak of the JoJo anime.

Alright before I get into this, this review most definitely represents the JoJo Franchise in it's entirety, as well as for Part 4 personally. JoJo to begin with, is something I could easily live for just to point that out. There are an infinite number of reasons why I say these words. Simply put the thrill and edge cutting uniqueness it packs, is INSANELY incredible. From character designs, color pallets, references, inventive world building, meaning/symbolism, culture, history, music, humor, mystery, and infinitely on....the JoJo Franchise is the embodiment of all these things. JoJo is literally everything. JoJo is the World itself, no puns. It isa international representation. It exhibits all aspects of the world, it's cultures and all it has to offer. This is why I say this. Araki is and ever beyond his time. \n\n
Out of all Parts in the series, Part 4 is the perfect example of what the series is. No matter how much flack it gets. It represents what JoJo truly is and even demonstrates how it will continue to evolve into even greater. It assures that the viewer pays homage to the series previous parts and even accentuates their importance. It is heavily story driven, and even still with this task successfully blossoms with color, a sense of realism, detail, fantasy, fiction, sci-fi, brilliant stand battles, etc. It contains this seamless flow that is impossible to not enjoy. It introduces really well designed characters and stands such as Kira and Rohan, Terunosuke Miyamoto, or Echoes and Heaven's Door; which in my personal opinion are insanely genius works of Araki. Moreover, there is this sense of resourcefulness in every character that you begin to see appreciate as the story unfolds. This meticulousness that is somehow sensational. On top of all this, Araraki does what he does best---having the ability to take a basic concept and make it seem as if you've never seen it before, hence exotic. It's able to maintain this eccentric, thrilling, interesting demeanor so flawlessly. This is why JoJo is on a higher echelon of quality. This is what JoJo is and that's why there's truly nothing like it.

There's a phrase that says "There's no place to go but up". However in Jojo's case, what would be up? The last Part ended a three Arc long storyline that had been going on since the very beginning of the Manga/Anime. So really, what could have higher stakes than this?
The answer was, surprisingly, quite simple: Lower the scale of the overall plot and give us a story with generally lower stakes. That, my friends, is the basis of the fourth Part of Jojo: Diamond Is Unbreakable (Or Diamond Is Not Crash as the infamous Duwang translation called it). So, let's Jam:
Story:
Similar to Part 3, Theplot is largely episodic, arguably even more so depending on your point of view. At least in Part 3, there was a definite end point that was established as early as the first Volume/Episode 3. It takes until almost the halfway point of Diamond Is Unbreakable for that end point to appear.


However, this kind of storytelling does have its pros. For one thing, it helps develop the setting quite well. The city of Morioh is house to many interesting locals and people, and the stationary setting allows the development of it quite well. There's also a mystery element involved here, what with the cast not even knowing who the main villain is for most of the Part.


I also feel this Part is better paced than the last one. Again, the episodic format allows for more explanation of the characters, but most of the time some of the main plot will be happening in the background of most episodes, so most of them don't really feel wasted, which is helped by the fact that Araki got a lot more creative for this Part.


Characters:


As always with Jojo, it's the characters that are the highlight. Jotaro and Joseph return, with Joseph mostly having a background role aside from his introductory arc, and Jotaro in turn taking up his Grandfather's role as a mentor. I quite liked this, as it gives it a weird feeling of inheritance, which is a recurring theme in the early parts of Jojo.


However it's the new cast that gets the most focus, as they deserve. Josuke is probably the most similar MC to Johnatan, however it would be a mistake to call him a gentleman given that he dresses like a Freaking delinquen. I quite like him, to say the least. However it's actually newcomer Hirose Koichi who gets the most development. We see him go from a weak willed kid who is frankly pathetic to (For lack of better words) a grown as man who has grown some freaking balls. And of course there's Nijimura Okuyasu, who's just so lovable you can't bring yourself to hate him.


Of course, the real star of the show is Kishibe Rohan. He's a kinda interesting take on the whole "Bad guy turns good guy" character, in that he doesn't really change even after his Face Turn. He's still an egocentric jackass who's only helping out because he's not stupid enough so as to let a serial killer run loose. He has also given us some beautiful lines, with my favorite being "Americans have shit taste".


And of course then there's Kira Yoshikage, the main antagonist. He's definitely a departure from precious antagonists, as he can be quite courteous and even polite, and overall he doesn't seem like that and a guy but instead just a normal life who just wants a normal life. But of course the guy is still a serial killer and a sociopath, so it's not as if it's an easy thing to achieve. There's also a soft reboot to his character after his second story arc that I won't even dare spoil due to how brillant it is.


And that's not even half the cast! There are so many other memorable characters I could mention, like Yamagishi Yukako, one of the earliest Yanderes (And still one of the best given that she actually develops as a character as she actually realizes than what she did was wrong), or even Shizuka Joestar, The invisible baby, or even the overly eccentric Italian chef Tonio Trussandi. Overall, Part 4 has one of the best casts in the series.


Animation:


Overall the show looks pretty good... in The Blu-Rays. Unfortunately the TV reproduction of the series had multiple off-model moments that I can't even begin to describe, with the most infamous being the "Quality Queen" shot. Now the Blu-Ray does fix this and overall, that combined with the lack of censorship increases the quality of the animation quite a lot. On the plus sude, no matter is it's the Blu-Ray or the TV Version the show looks great on movement.


Sound:


The soundtrack is once again great. It goes for a mix of heavy techno combined with calmer classically instrumented scenes for an absolutely delicious combination. As far as the Openings go, "Crazy Noisy Bizarre Town" (Both in EDM and Disco flavor) is absolutely fabulous and entertaining, "Chase" is just a great rock song and "Great Days" carries a hopeful tone that cannot be matched, especially the version used for the final credits that brings together the singers of all previous Openings.


Voice Acting:


The cast is great. Ono Daisuke and The Late Great Ishizuka Unsho come back and do a great job as always. Of course, they're not the Stars, of the show, oh no, the rest of the cast is. I don't have much experience with Ono Yuuki as of writing this, but I think he did a pretty good job as Josuke. Takagi Wataru was also great as Okuyasu, and it's easy to see why he was one of the two Seiyuus kept from the CC2 games (The other Being Yamaguchi Kappei as Shigechi).


But of course, above then all in terms of quality is Morikawa Toshiyuki as Kira. While Sephiroth might still be his most iconic role, this is hands down my favorite role of his. The guy just completely sold Kira's sociopathy, and overall did a great job at also sounding like a mostly normal sounding guy.


Of course, the rest of the cast is great as well. We have talents such as Toyoguchi Megumi, Kaji Yuuki, Ohara Sayaka, Moribuko Showtaro, Noto Mamiko and even the one and only Chiba Shigeru. Overall, Part 4 continues the Anime's trend of having a fantastic cast.


Overall:


In the end, Part 4 is nothing but fun. While it may not be flawless, I can honestly why more than a few people consider this their favorite part, and it's definitely among my three favorites. It's got it all: Drama, action, mystery, comedy... there's a little bit of everything in this one. Needless to say, this was definitely my favorite anime of the year it came out in.


Final Score: 9/10

The MAL score suggests diamond-like quality, but this part 4 of JoJo's adventures is much more comparable to a polished crystal. It's very clean, impressively shaped, but ultimately, while it's pretty to look at, it won't make you rich.
Considering only the entertainment value, this anime is amazing in every aspect, it's audio-visually pleasing, characters have enough room for development, storytelling is decent, the occasional comedy is on point. I actually enjoyed watching it more than around 90% of shows on my list...
However, that's it. I had a blast while watching, but the fact that I completed it today will not be on my mind tomorrow,which is a shame, really. This emotional fade-out is something I expect from a top 50-ish anime.


Even without the additional value, "Diamond is Unbreakable" would probably deserve it's place in MAL ranking, if it wasn't so ridiculously flawed.


The story starts of strong with the introduction of main protagonists, has an acceptable finish, but the middle part, which uses mostly the 1-problem-per-2-episodes formula, is kind of hit-and-miss. Almost every episode contains some form of convenient bullcrap. Jotaro ignores the effectiveness of his own power, Koichi and the others are being purposely dumb, blind and whatnot... typical anime shenanigans. While this is acceptable in a battle shounen, it doesn't complement the criminal/thriller aspect of the story very well.

Compared to the other parts of JoJo, the twists and climaxes are much more consistent in terms of quality, but that's not necessarily a good thing. While "Stardust Crusaders" had it's pathetic lows, the last 7 or so episodes were more memorable than anything from "Diamond is Unbreakable" simply because the hype curve went from close-to-zero right off the charts.


The best word I can find to describe the art of "Diamond is Unbreakable" is "outstanding", because it really stands out in terms of colors, art style and animation. The animation feels less fluid as it felt in the prequels, but it is still above average. The lighter and cooler color palette is fresh and interesting. I also have the impression that the drawing of characters has improved quite a lot (might be a thing that transitioned from manga)

Opening themes are good, but in my opinion way worse than the first 4 JoJo openings. Endings are about the same quality as they were before (=great).

Soundtrack goes well with situations and the art style, but the score is not very memorable by itself.


Characters are not very balanced personality-wise. There are some good and at least somehow complex characters like Josuke, Jotaro, Kira, Rohan, but there are also annoying simpletons like Koichi, Hazamada, Yukako. However, as I've pointed out in the beginning, each one of them has enough time to shine and they are used often and properly, which is quite unusual and commendable, even though this notably delays the story progression. Quite a shame, really, this would have been a great slice of life drama setting, but it's a battle-driven story instead... yare yare daze.


To sum it all up, the 4th part of JoJo's adventures might be the best one of the pack (I still enjoyed "Battle Tendency" more), but it has it's objective flaws which shouldn't be overlooked. I would argue that the MAL community overrates it a little, but that's just my insignificant impression. Still a strong 7/10 (story 5 + 2 for the execution of the thriller aspect in battle environment, art 10, sound 7, characters 6,5, enjoyment 10)

I'll get right to the point and say that I thought Diamond is Unbreakable was a solid OK, it wasn't terrible but it was definitely the weakest of the 4 parts so far in my opinion.
SPOILER WARNING: While I'll try not to give away spoiler moments in the show, I will talk about missed opportunities or things that I think the show could have done which basically implies that it didn't happen hence the spoiler warning (mouthful lol)
Story - One of the two things I liked LEAST about the show. It started off pretty interesting with the introduction of our new hero and how he'sconnected to the JoJo lineage but after the chili pepper arc I felt like we didn't need to be in this town of Morioh anymore. Everything afterwards seemed to just kind of drag and then we got the villian of the week episodes and this new main antagonist that didn't really resonate until MUCH later in the show. The story and adventure of the previous JoJo parts were what made the show so interesting and fun but this felt very contained which made it a little boring.


Art & Sound - Far and away the BEST part of this show is the animation and music choices. Each character has a unique look about them and the opening/ending songs perfectly fit the bizarre nature of this show. Honestly at this point, it's pretty much a given that watching this show will be visually satisfying even if the story itself is a weak.


Characters - This is what bugged me the most about this show, the emptiness of a lot of these characters which is  a shame because we spent 39 episodes with them. The main character Jousuke is pretty good and resemble a young Joseph Joestar with his wit and humor. I really liked the creative ways he would use his stand. Kira as the main antagonist in the later half was weak at first but he definitely became more formidable as time went on. Truly a scary villian almost on the same level as Dio. Kouichi was probably the only character that showed development and it was apparent in his stand that evolved as the show went on. Okuyasa... sigh the DEFINITION of a missed opportunity since he probably has one of the coolest and most interesting stands but does basically nothing with it after the chili pepper arc. I think it was a huge writing mistake to make a character that dumb have a stand that interesting. Joutarou was like a mentor and had some standout moments while Joseph was practically handicapped and sidelined to be a caretaker of some random invisible baby. Last character I want to talk about is Rohan who was intoduced late into the show as something of a villian but quickly became one of my favorite characters and added so much to the show with his interesting Stand and investigative skills. Everyone else, hair stand girl, chef man, makeup woman, Shigechi etc were all pretty much forgettable


Enjoyment - When the show was good it was GOOD. The beginning ARC and last like 10 episodes had me on the edge of my seat, biting my nails, etc it's just that middle portion of complete nonsense and no plot that drove me crazy. A must watch for fans.


Overall/Closing thoughts - I think this was good but it could have been MUCH better. It's my least favorite arc to date with a story that was too contained in a town that I didn't really care that much about. Hope Part 5 adds more fun and adventure when (if) that comes out!

I’ll admit, I have some mixed feelings on Jojo’s as a whole. While it’s certainly wonderfully ridiculous and unique, I tend to find the characters kind of bland and one-note, and some running gags to be overused. That doesn’t mean I hate it, it just means it’s a crapshoot on whether or not I enjoy certain parts.
Thankfully, Diamond is Unbreakable is the most consistent Jojo’s has been so far, not as ludicrously fun as Battle Tendency, but by far the most solid storytelling the series has ever had. Unlike previous parts, which were big adventure epics where the fate of the world hung in thebalance, this one centers around a single town afflicted by a Twin Peaks-esque murder mystery. The first half of the series is almost a slice-of-life story, with our new cast of characters just hanging around and bumping into Stand users every now and then. But that’s actually a compliment, as this extended downtime with them really helps solve Jojo’s biggest problem: it develops a large, likable cast of characters with a wide variety of personalities, motivations, and powers.


Our latest Jojo, Josuke Higashikita, is especially charming thanks to the fact that unlike previous iterations, he’s very much an underdog. Lacking the easy confidence of Jonathan, Joseph and Jotaro, he instead exudes an endearing dorkiness that matches well with his Stand’s more compassionate, defensive abilities. He’ll never top Joseph in terms of sheer entertainment value, but he’s by far the easist Jojo to sympathize with.


The rest of the cast acquit themselves well too. Koichi is a coward who grows into his courage and new abilities well, Okuyasku is an entertaining dimwit with a heart of gold, and Jotaro’s stoic presence plays much better as a support to a group of bigger characters than as the lead of Stardust Crusaders. Even the side characters, like Yukako and the hilarious Italian chef, are given more depth and personality than pretty much anyone before. And, of course, the murderous Yoshikage Kira is a nastier, more personal villain than anything we’ve faced before, leading to some incredibly tense encounters and some surprisingly well-earned pathos.


On top of that, the creativity in the Stands themselves has grown exponentially. From the ever-evolving Echoes, to a rat that can cube meat, to the electrifying Red Hot Chili Pepper, to that one weird Stand that was just a telephone Pylon, the battles in this part are some of the most creative mind games the series has ever come up with. Heck, there are even some Stand users who aren’t enemies, but are just part of the town, leading to some very different encounters than what we’re used to.


While I still have some problems with the series as a whole- too much damn narration, too much casual sexism- I greatly enjoyed Part 4, and I'm definitely looking forward to Vento Aureo this coming fall. Here's hoping it keeps the streak alive.

So uh, another short review so you guys don't have to read all of these paragraphs.
In short, the writing gets a lot better, all of the characters are more or less likeable and the soundtrack is still amazing. The monster of the week format is still there, but done better and in a wonderful, trippy, charming static setting. The general atmosphere is akin to a typical slice of life comedy - riddled with urban legends and horror that disrupt it - which is literally the ongoing theme throughout the season. 
The manga left more of an impression on me when reading because of Araki's amazingart style and color scans provided by Shueishas's JOJO-D. The anime tried to mimic that tone but, in my opinion, failed to do so because they focused more on static stills and stylish shots rather than dynamic animation. Some would argue this is a stylistic choice but for this medium, it doesn't realy work well in my opinion. \n\n
Overall this is a strong 9, if you're 3 seasons in and you want to continue with more Jojo if only to see where this show goes and to see the new setting, characters, soundtrack, animation, and fights - definitely watch this all the way. The villain of this part is probably the best villain of all time (the Queen references and American Psycho/David Bowie inspiration definitely help with this). Part 4 is among the two best written parts out of all of the Jojo parts.

Jojo's bizarre adventure: diamond is unbreakble is the 4th part of Jojo's bizarre adventure. The preceding parts of Jojo have been overall enjoyable, but noticeably flawed, to the detriment of my enjoyment. Is this the case for DIU? No!!!!!
STORY 9/10
The story is f*** amazing! It begins in the small Japanese town known as Morioh. Jotaro (from part 3) goes there to see a reletive of his. Josuke, his uncle, is now attending high school (yes, the uncle of a 30-something year old man is attending high school), and making friends with little people, a manga artist, a yandere and there's also a few serial killers.The actual story doesn't kick in until halfway through the show. Before then, it's a collection of stories about the mystery behind Morioh and it's residents. Once the story actually starts it's OH MA GAAAHHHD!!!!! The last 10 episodes or so are as intense as the Cold War, the main antagonist is one of the best anime villains out there, and there's actual character arcs!! Starting this show, I was worried that this would be another part 3; a collection of useless stories that hardly impact the overall story. This is not the case. There are exactly 4 episodes that are as formulaic and pointless as the average stardust episode. There were plenty of times where I thought it was going to take the generic route again, but I was quickly proved wrong after seeing some of the most unconventional and cleverly-written episodes of Jojo ever!


CHARACTERS 10/10

OH MA GAAAHHHD!!!!! The main cast of characters are Josuke, the charismatic Jojo of this story, his friend Koichi, a short, puny kid whose character arc is one of the best ones in this show. Rohan, a seclusive manga artist, and Jotaro is back!!! The first half has a similar style to stardust crusaders; a different character fights someone every episode or 2. Again, a delight, seeing every character have their own time in the spotlight. The last time I watched a Jojo part, the villains as a whole were pointless and never brought up again and were 1 dimensional. While there are very few of those types of people in it, every "villain" in this show is super important! Almost all of the villains appear again in later episodes and contribute somehow. The greatest delight is when a villain character now becomes a good guy and fights alongside them. Actually, a majority of the villains are dynamic and developed enough to effectively do that.


ART 8/10

Jojo's art style continues to impress me. Although it's still not as trippy and colorful as part 2, and the characters don't look as real as they do in part 3, what this show has going for it is color palette. A lot of purple, yellow, green, pink and blue make up what this show looks like. Not to mention the sound, which is also great. The 2nd opening is one of my favorite OPs ever, and although the soundtrack doesn't have stand-out tracks, it's still fun to listen to.


OVERALL 9/10

Jojo part 4 improves upon Jojo in almost every way imaginable. From Pink Floyd references, to invisible babies, to memes, this show is great! My only apparent flaw is the pacing of the first half, and the few episodes that aren't important to the grand story. I give it my best recommendation, and urge you to get into Jojo ASAP. It's things like this that makes someone appreciate Jojo so much. If you're anything like me, you'll watch part 1 and 2 and say "why is this so popular?" Trust me, don't give up on it.

David Production's most recent adaptation of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure remains true to its source material and pulls off the most fabulous iteration in one of the franchise's best installments. Rich in action and interesting Stand fights, Diamond is not Crash or Diamond is Unbreakable is the epitome of JJBA's long-standing popularity as a unique battle shonen.
DiU is based off the fourth part of JJBA, centering around a new JoJo, Josuke Higashikata, the illegitimate son of Joseph Joestar, and a fifteen-year murder mystery that befalls Morioh, his hometown...or so how it goes.
The story starts off fairly slow, retaining some monster-of-the-week elements from Stardust Crusaders. The goodside to this is that we get to see Hirohiko Araki flex his creative ability to deliver far more entertaining fights that rival the Egypt Arc from Part 3. New Stands are introduced and battles get more entertaining and unpredictable in later episodes as well, especially the brilliant final arc that is possibly one of the highest points of the franchise. The bad side, aside from the fact that it becomes formulaic in setup, is that it causes some unnecessary filler.


Take for example the episode about Tonio Trussardi, the chef with Stand powers. While with all due respect that his Stand is awesome, it doesn't really do much aside from being novelty. What's more is that for the rest of the show, he never gets some time to shine at all, and becomes an irrelevant background character in later arcs.


However, what's interesting is that some fights may be filler to some extent, some episodes work as filler to actually set up future plot development. It allowed good use of foreshadowing to the eventual reveal of the series' main villain, through an episode about make-up.


Speaking of foreshadowing, this might be the most well thought-out JoJo plot yet, and you can clearly see that it had a planned direction of things to come. My favorite foreshadowing of the show is when they use Morioh Radio to reference future episodes. Almost any instance of Morioh Radio playing indicates a plot point that may or may not arrive at the next episode, and it creates a great feeling of anticipation for viewers with keen eyes.


But most of this smart structuring wouldn't be as apparent if not for the great color palette accompanying it. Morioh's sky, for one, does not have a permanent color, and it can be any entry from the color wheel except blue but still manage to be beautiful. I commend David Productions for going all-out with their colors this time, and I may not be an expert on the science of colors, but I know when something is visually appealing. Praise unto Hirohiko Araki, of course, for being continuously playful with colors, and it is in Part 4 where his fashion statement emphasizes the character designs even more.


As colorful as his designs are the characters themselves—and we get a number of significant Stand users whose intentions aren't to become one-hit wonders like Stardust Crusaders had. Most of them remain in the story, actually forming an ensemble of Stand users that aren't just Josuke and the main cast, and get some time in the spotlight to show off their powers as well. Discussing all of them would be pretty long, so I will just focus on the main protagonist and antagonist.


Keeping up with this colorful cast, we also meet the most down-to-earth JoJo yet: Josuke Higashikata is more quirky than Stardust's Jotaro, and his attitude breathes fresh air into JJBA. He isn't a bad person, nor isn't he exactly a goody-two-shoes either; he lands on the balance as a guy taking advantage of people in the least hurtful way possible, and a headstrong personality much similar to his father. While they are similar, Josuke could be likened to a watered-down version of Joseph, and at first he may be less entertaining to watch. Through time, though, we get to see more of his playful side and humble attitude, making him another fun JoJo.


Yet as much as good of a JoJo Josuke is, the praise of the series often goes to its main antagonist, Yoshikage Kira. Lauded as one of the best well-written villains in the franchise yet, Kira's characterization puts him at a significant one-up over the franchise's poster villain, Dio Brando. A sociopathic serial killer who has been silently covering tracks of his crimes for the past fifteen years prior to the beginning of the show, Kira isn't written as all-powerful as Dio, nor is he written as some invincible character that can stop time. He is on the same footing as much as the cast is, and it is this constant friction with the characters' plans that makes him and the series at a higher level than the previous installments. How he also gets more screentime than other JJBA villains also highlight his character development, making him the most fleshed-out villain so far.


With short mention of the supporting characters, I want to give praise to Rohan Kishibe, the town's resident mangaka for his quirky attitude and great foil to Josuke. Joseph and Jotaro also return as supporting characters, and their presence in the cast sort of gives a satisfying feeling for keeping up with JJBA through these past three installments.


The animation has been keeping up, too—while David Production's animation isn't something you would call stellar, you could definitely see the effort in their production values, from the amazing transitions to the three well-detailed OPs—of which of course particular praise goes to Great Days. Everything in this show is more fluid than the previous ones, keeping a dynamic gain for viewer attention aside from being mere lip flaps that I swear were one half of Stardust Crusaders' animation.


The voice cast does give their characters justice, although I would have preferred Rohan's game VA, Hiroshi Kamiya as his voice actor and not Takahiro Sakurai. It boggles my mind also that Koichi's VA is Yuki Kaji, considering how high-pitched the guy often screams. Daisuke Ono's portrayal of Jotaro just the way he should be portrayed—calm, serious, and collected, is still one of the highlights of the cast's overall performance. You will somehow miss Takehito Koyasu, though...you won't be hearing those mudas anymore.


With JoJo's Bizarre Adventure's firm justification of the term "bizarre," the franchise's initial entries weren't something you would call the best, but they sure know how to keep a person enjoyed. With the addition of DiU to the anime franchise, though, it does not only cement a new wave of uniqueness, but also a strong candidate to be one of the best solid-written action series out there.

Spoiler-Free Review
Jojo's Bizarre Adventure is a (in)famous franchise for its Bizarre and Wacky Story and Characters, the Antagonists are no exception. From a bodybuilder gay vampire in Part 1 to a... Serial Killer that has a Hand Fetish in Part 4... Huh... 
ANYWAY, Where i am going with this is that Jojo's Bizarre Adventure's strongest point lies in its Characters and Bizarre Story. Diamond Is Unbreakable or better known as Part 4 is a great example of that. The Heroes of this Part all have their own unique Personalities and Quirks, but some are really underused and have their screen-time only once or twice aftertheir own arc. This is the only problem that Part 4 has with its Characters. \n
The Story isn't really as Bizarre as the other parts, but it's one, If not, The Best in its whole franchise (and this is coming from a Manga Reader). It didn't make much changes from the manga, but it's basically the same. It did cut some conversations and lines, but that's it.\n
The Openings are as good as ever (but there's no CGI anymore :[) and the OST is a masterpiece, every character theme fits. \n
The Art is good, but the Animation can get awkward sometimes.\n
If you haven't even touched Jojo yet, then what are you doing, mate? \n
I would definitely recommend it to everyone to try it out.\n\n

Jojo's Bizarre Adventure: Diamond is not Crash is one of the most disappointing adaptions that I've seen of a classic shounen manga. You might be thinking, "well a 6/10 isn't that bad". WRONG, this anime should be a 10/10. It should have fixed the small problems of the manga and improved on it - like what David Production did to the previous parts! Well so what went wrong?
To start, part 4 is where Araki's distinct style starts to emerge and unfortunately the adaption fails to capture that style and ends up looking completely different from what it should. Which wouldn't be so bad if DavidProduction didn't sacrifice the character's detail in the process. Personally, I hate the way that the lips and the noses are drawn in this anime. I also found the music to be a little tame in comparison to the previous parts, which made the fights alot less exciting. 


What this anime does get right however, is establishing a somewhat lighthearted and colourful aesthetic right from the start (so that it immediately sets it self apart from stardust crusaders). And it does this through the fantastic and vibrant colour pallet. This is better than the manga, which instead slowly begins to form an identity throughout it's run. Moreover this adaptation's pacing is perfect - no time wasted all killer no filler.


Overall I would say you're much better off reading the manga, but still worth checking out regardless because of its positives.

I've been very vocal against Jojo and its series due to its immense reliance on asspulls, but this part is a marked improvement over the earlier parts, and for once the villain is neither brain-dead nor completely overpowered. I would recommend skipping parts 1 and 3, and start at 2 or jump to 4. The stories have distinct settings, so I wouldn't say you'll lose much of the plot relative to the time you'll waste.
Firstly, there's really only one villain that matters. It only makes sense, because we all know good people tend to work together while evil people are more selfish and only worktogether when they share a common goal. There's plenty of other villains, but not in the way of part 3 "I'll give up my life for my lord, but I refuse to work with his other servants.", and more misguided than evil. In a way you could see this part as more slice of life than other parts in the Jojo series, which were more along the lines of an epic "The world is in danger as a super powerful villain aims to dominate the world, and there's only a handful of people to stop him."


The pacing is pretty decent, except for the ending which felt a bit rushed. I prefer this sort of pacing to the usual Jojo pacing, as it feels like it's developing the characters and setting to be more realistic and easier to imagine/picture, whereas the usual one is just rushing to tell the story, which is in contrast flatter, more generic, and less story, more tool.


The main character, Josuke, manages to utilise his ability creatively. You'd think his ability is more fitting of a support character, but he holds his own fairly often, although mostly because his stand already possesses high combat ability to begin with. This is in contrast to part 3, with half the fights being "Punch the hell out of them, works every time" or "Gotta go fast". Instead, Josuke punches the hell out of other things /s.

The kid is/kids are useful, rather than just being a cheerleading sidekick like in earlier parts.


Although there were still a few asspulls in this part, they were easier to swallow as they involved things that weren't explained because there was no reason/opportunity to do so, rather than "how convenient that this should happen" or villain stupidity.


Things I did not like:

- Why was Joseph Joestar in this part? He did nothing, except adopt some kid that also did nothing. There's other characters that don't really further the plot, but at least they were either funny or feel-good, unlike these two.

- Okuyasu was under-utilised, another victim of Araki's tendency to create powerful/absolute characters. Half of the reason could be he's an idiot though, just like the other idiot wielding a powerful Stand.

- The animal was way too strong for a mere animal, they're not supposed to be smarter than DIO but they are. 


I would say this anime is more deserving of 7/10, but after considering that MAL scores are often inflated, and that this part is much better than the first 3 Jojo parts which I've already given a savage score for, I've decided to bump this up to 8/10.

I'm writing this review at about halfway through Part 4. I've seen Parts 1-3 as well, and am working my way up to Part 5, which is airing at the time of this review. As I promise to always do in my reviews, there will be NO SPOILERS WHATSOEVER FOR THIS PART. However, THERE WILL BE SPOILERS REGARDING PREVIOUS JOJO PARTS.
TLDR: 4/8/9/8/10 Overall: 7/10
Story: 4/10. This is, by far, the weakest aspect of this Part, especially when compared to the rest of the Parts. There is no real overarching goal that spans the whole Part. The first few episodes have some plotline that it looselyfollows: finding out why all these new Stand users have been appearing in Morioh, despite the death of DIO. However, this is resolved early, and it leads to the feeling that now there is no goal for the protagonists. While the plot synopsis above says that they are investigating the disappearances in Morioh, at episode 20, almost no mention of these disappearances, aside from the fact that they are happening, has occurred. Once the mystery of the Stands is resolved, it almost becomes a Slice of Life as it follows the lives of the main Stand users. Because of this, I give the story a low rating. While one may argue that I'm just not in far enough for the main story to manifest, I'd contest that by episode 20, the story should have fully materialized by now.


Art: 8/10. I really love the character designs, especially the characters and how they dress. The show really does carry a great 1999 air about it, fitting the setting of the show well. It's like watching the Fresh Prince of Bel Air: Japan Edition. 


Sound: 9/10. The OPs are both great. Yes, even Chase, the one that gets flak. The ED is ok, not memorable or provocative like previous ones, but it's ok. The best sound, by far, is Josuke's theme, with a steady beating of the bass and a slow, menacing guitar riff. It's foreboding, and it's by far my favorite effect in the series.


Character: 8/10. I want to give this a 10. I really do. Josuke, Koichi, Okuyasu, the enemy Stand users, they're all great. What brings it down for me, sadly, is Jotaro. He's not the snarky, witty man he was in Part 3. Of course, now he's 28 years old, so supposedly he's matured, but it feels more like he's been stripped of his personality to highlight Josuke's. That being said, Josuke is very likable. He's reminiscent of Jonathon Joester, being kind and helping others, and having a sense of honor, but also being schemey sometimes, as a 16-year-old should be. 


Enjoyment: 10/10. Despite the weakness of the story, almost all of the episodes are entertaining. There are villains you'll love, villains you'll hate, and what's interesting is seeing which enemy Stand users end up becoming friends with the gang. It isn't like Part 3, where they all join in the first five episodes. The new additions to the gang as the show goes on helps keep it fresh. In addition to adding new characters, some characters recur much later following their introduction, making each character feel less like a throwaway Stand Of The Week ordeal. Josuke and Okuyasu are both fantastic. Koichi will grow on you. And the others, who I won't mention, are generally welcome additions to the cast. Also, when Jotaro uses his Stand, it's fucking awesome, I only wish he would use it more. 


Overall: 7/10. In general, it's very good. Sadly, I feel that it pales in comparison to other Parts. Part 3 felt like an epic odyssey as the group traveled halfway across the world in pursuit of DIO. Part 4 feels like you're following the footsteps of some high schools, without a clear goal in sight. This really brings the show down, given how the other parts were pretty plot-driven. The characters make up for this, though. Most Stand battles are interesting, although some can feel dragged out or boring (see: Heaven's Door, which I felt could've been cut to 1 episode instead of 2). All this being said, it's worth watching, if only to catch up on the show before Part 5. If you've watched all Parts up to this point, you'll enjoy this as well. The expansion of Stands helps, and they feel more balanced. It's no longer like Jotaro can just kick everyone's ass with Star Platinum, and each Stand has notable limitations that make fights more intense. 


In summary: Stand battles are better than in Part 3 for the most part, but the plot is much weaker than in any other part. Characters are as likable as before, maybe moreso, with the exception of Jotaro, who feels washed out. Overall, worth a watch if you've liked all the Parts, especially Part 3, but you probably won't like it more than the others.

I like this. Whenever I see Jojo, I feel like I'm ready to become Stroheim and praise the Jojo fanbase instead of Germany's science. I gotta say, I have NO DIGNITY. Greato daze, as they say over there.
Well, for my review, I gotta point out some stuff. The story was... a bit bland at the start, but when Kira came in, everything got hyped and serious. I had a... how do I say this... I had an erection when I saw Kira's style of living and fighting. The story was a bit slow at the start but was able to introduce the cast to usand present them before we got to the climax.


The art - like you know, David Production and their constant change of coloring and scenes are what keeps you going sometimes. Their animation style may have downgraded from 3D to 2D, but this is fine. It adds the emphasis and bizarre colors of the scene.


The sound - god, the songs and the themes are really good. They really play out the bizarre note of the series and make you want to sing along. Some of the themes go along anything in the outside world.

Overall - recommended to friends and those that watched Jojo.

Part 4 is the most enjoyable, crazy, stylish, brash and well JoJo's part animated thus far (part 5 airing at the time of this review). It takes the concepts of stands that we saw in part 3 and added so much insanity to it. The crazy thing about this conglomeration of insane powers is none of them feel overpowered or under powered. Each villain the boys encounter and each of the series protagonist gets both chances to shine and chances to prove themselves. While part 3 may have had some interesting concepts for how fights go it doesn't hold a candle to some of theway fights play out in Diamond in Unbreakable. That was one of my favorite parts of this season was the amount of times our heroes got into fights either at a complete disadvantage or way out of their comfort zone. This creates great moments of creativity and ingenuity in each of the fights. That's the beauty of this part, niche powers in situation where either they can thrive or prove their worth in an underdog scenario.   


Instead of the typical approach to shounen series were during of random ass-pull power ups, Jojo's fights tend to play like more like a puzzle. Due to the nature of unique and niche powers the story looks to constantly put the Jobro's out of their comfort zone to showcase how quick witted and resourceful our heroes are. We notice small cracks in the armour of opponents or understand how the power works and how to effectively turn the tables. 


One of the major parts that part 3 felt like it was missing was more of a cohesive world. Granted that world was well, our world at the time the events of stardust crusaders. The world of Morioh feels incredibly lively. Major events and minor fights usually leave behind some sort of "landmark" for the eye catcher. These typically giving some background of the area the event or fight adding to the overall town of Morioh. But it's not just the set pieces that add to the overall charm of Morioh. Instead of the usual formula of front loading our main cast and having very little change in that cast we have a smaller main cast and a larger set of recurring characters. These characters were all usually minor villains turned friend by the Jobro's. In turn most of the recruited side characters help out the main cast in some of the more important fights. This approach helps with the slow, small town vibes Morioh gives off with constantly running into familiar faces and friends just going about your business. 


The only complaint I would have is there wasn't a major goal of the plot at the beginning and didn't have much focus there. But I don't really mind cause as it was trying to find its story we got some really fun and exciting episodes. This creates this near peaceful feeling to the town of Morioh. Making the juxtaposition of our primary villain all the more scary rears their head. Best part animated so far and I'm excited to see if the next parts are able to live up to part 4.

THIS REVIEW WILL CONTAIN HEAVY SPOILERS FROM PART 4, PLEASE READ AT YOUR OWN RISK!
JoJo no Kimyou na Bouken: Diamond wa Kudakenai (or in english, JoJo's Bizarre Adventure, Diamond is Unbreakable) is the fourth part in the series and arguably, the best that has been animated so far. This will be a review.
STORY: 8
The reason that im giving this a 8 and not a 9, is because this part has some problems in storywriting, the main problem of all, is the huge cast of characters and how they are basically useless on the fight with Yoshikage Kira/Kosaku Kawajiri, The only important supportive characters in thispart are: 


Josuke Higashikata

Okuyasu Nijimura

Jotaro Kujo

Koichi Hirose

Rohan Kishibe (The real MVP in this part)

Hayato Kawajiri. (The real MVP in this part)


This are the ""Main Characters on this part"", but the problem erradicates in this part has a lot of characters that mean a pretty much a really big danger for the main characters (or stands that could be helpful on the fight against kira), but as always, the mayority of this "Villian of the Week" are either Forgotten/Killed/Became good and later basically useless, (for example, Yukako).


The plot starts with Keicho as a villian, later to be reedemed and killed by Red Hot Chili Pepper,  after 12-15 episodes of villian of the week, RHCP is defeated and sended to jail, and later nothing is happening rater that presenting new characters or useless conflicts.


OBVIOUSLY this changes a lot when Kira Yoshikage is first introduced, the story becomes very straight-forward and this is a good thing for the part, im not going too deep on this, but the final fight is very good, and satisfactory like JoJo has used to do.



ART: 9.


The style of drawing in this series is not focused in more slim bodies and focused in fashion, which still has the typical JoJo style of art. 


The animation in some episodes has decreased, (Not to the point of Gintama: Shirogane no Tamashii), but still you can notice it mostly in the episode when Killer Queen is introduced.


Overall this is fixed in the bluray, the animation and movement is very fluid and very, very good. 


Sound: JoJo again, surprise us with his incredible use of sounds in stand effects, and his unique OST.


Obviously im not a expert at reviewing ost, but i could say, i enjoyed this ost a lot, The best theme is Kira Yoshikage theme.


CHARACTERS: 8


The characters has improved quite lot compared to the Stardust Crusaders (or Polnareff, Joseph and Jotaro with other ppl Adventure), the characters feel a lot more like humans and are well builded. I would say the best character is that has the most character development is Koichi Hirose. This is proved in the last episode of DIU, in the speech of Jotaro. BUT STILL, Rohan Kishibe and Josuke Higashikata are my favorite characters in this part.


Yoshikage Kira is probably one of the best villians in Anime in general, the psycopath personality is well used and is well balanced not to the point of edgyness. He recieves my Respect.


ENJOYMENT: 9


I enjoyed this part like any other JoJo part, it was a nice ride, fun and emotional in some parts, (Not at the level of SC in emotional). The best episodes were the final ones with Kosaku Kawajiri and Kira Yoshikage.


Overall, i enjoyed Diamond is Unbreakable a lot. The characters and the setting is well used and his worldbuilding is done correctly, also the whole Kira Yoshikage Arc was probably the highest point on this part.


FINAL SCORE: 8.
