This is anime is for mature eyes only. The Jojo series is a real treat to anyone who watches anime. It is however violent and this season is no exception. Blood lingers throughout the season and the main characters are fickle but admirable. It's really colorful yet realistic. For example there is Rohan who I suspect is a surrogate character for the author to display a large portion of his personality. I could be wrong but he seems to have an eye for the world in the same way that the mangaka would. Jojo and his classmates fight menaces to the town along with Joutaro.It's been really fun watching both the sub and dub of this series. I'll be angry if it doesn't end as great as it started. But again be warned the villans are well thought out and I hope I'm not taking a stab at the showrunners by saying it's startling how well thought out they are and how the good guys are not quite photo-esq heroes. But maturity aside it's great. I'm a little past halfway through. the soundtrack is the best too. It rekindled my love for oldies.

The Diamond JoJo arc was the most entertaining arc for me. Now I guess I will have to explain what kind of person I am. I never watched any anime that keeps its focus on fighting scenes all the way to the end. I never watched any anime that failed to make its characters interesting, no less the plot. I liked anime that had a greater theme; for example in Prisma Illya (yes, I know it's not popular), the relationship between the yuri girls moved me a lot. Maybe a better example is Higurashi, which I liked a lot. Diamond was able to keep aguy like me engrossed. 


Araki, the author of the manga series, said that his favorite character among the Jojo series was Josuke, the guy in this arc, because Josuke was the only character among all the ones he created portrayed as a 'friend.' Maybe because the protagonist was portrayed as a friend, the whole arc felt like it was maintaining a relationship with me. Diamond was like watching a friend making jokes, and it made you, the viewer, one of the characters in the show - maybe as a fellow person living in Morioh, which is the town that this arc focuses on.


One thing I never liked about the JoJo series exists and it happens to be that it still applies to Diamond. It's the kind of story progression where you introduce one villain in one episode and a new villain in the other, just to show how the protagonist beats each of them up. That kind of progression always felt clunky. But this element that I disliked felt less clunky in Diamand than it did in series such as Stardust. Regardless of how the story progresses though, each episode of every JoJo series is still a 10/10.


Thanks to David Production for making such a fantastic anime with amazing art and music. I enjoyed it very much. Maybe some day when I have money, I will owe my debt.

Jojo's bizzare adventure diamond is unbreakable is the 4th part of jojo and currently the last one adapted into an anime (Not including the Rohan OVAs) and follows the story of Higashikate Josuke, Part 2's jojo, Joseph Joestar, illegitamte son in his bizzare town of Morioh.
Lets get the main thing out of the way: Josuke is (IMO) the best Jojo in the (anime) series due to the simple fact that he doesnt have 1 defining characteristic. Jonathan was a noble and honorable man, Joseph was the witty and underhanded tactics guy and Jotaro was just the biggest badass to exist. Josuke just doesnt have thatand thats what makes him gureto. Hes just a kid going on weird adventures with his friends in his small town while having fun.


ART:

While the shift between part 3 and 4 were pretty drastic, they fit Araki's ever evolving drawing style, managing to capture the feel of the part 4 manga

one highlight i would like to make is Jotaro, going from looking like every single male in part 3 with hard lines on his face and a strong chin, to being a more relaxed and nicer on the eyes, which also reflect Jotaro's growth in part 4, but we'll talk about that in characters


CHARACTERS:

Part 4 is the first part to make the cast feel like actual people and not just be "Jojo's friends" aside from pre established characters such as Joseph in part 3

every character has their own story, motivations, personality, relationships and emotions, while still feeling like actual, real people.

Jotaro is no longer the edgy, black wearing angry punk he was in part 3 and is not taking on a mentor role for Josuke and a friend for Koichi, although old habits die hard as he still cant stand screaming girls.


Koichi is a friend of Josuke dragged into the world of STANDS by the mysterious "Stand arrow" which grants him his stand "ECHOES" which gets strobger and more powerful as Koichi grows as a person and is pushed to his maximum mental capablities.


Okuyasu is the brother of Keicho Nijimura, the owner of the stand arrow and evantual plot device for Okusayu's character development. After growing up in an abusive household with his father turning into an ugly creature due to him selling his soul to DIO and being implanted with a flesh bud, which after DIO's death destroy his human cells. now Keicho was the one wearing the pants in teh family and was very harsh with Okusayu, leading him into a life of anger and aggresivness, with an overpowered stand, THE HAND, not being used properly due to his narrow mindedness.


everything i wrote above is terribly watered down for the sake of not writing for literal hours, but once you watch the show, you'll understand.


And now is where we step into *SPOILER TERITTORY* due to the nature of the show and the antagonist


so last warning SPOILERS AHEAD




STORY:

The story is all about the Morioh Warriors, Josuke, Koichi, Okuyasu, Jotaro and Rohan trying to stop the secret serial killer of the town, Yoshikage Kira.

Kira is a villian we havent seen before in Jojo's since the reason for him being the antagonist isnt him being a threat to humanity, On paper the entirety of part 4 could not happen and Kira could still be alive and it'd have little to no impact on the story of Jojos as a whole. HE WANTS TO LIVE A QUIET LIFE. Which is what makes the fact that he has been killing for 15 years without being caught all the more terrefying. But he doesnt kill for the sake of killing, he kills for the sake of taking the women he kill's hands for his own pleasure, often treating them as his "girlfriend". after Koichi achives Echoes act 3, he encounters Kira and gets destroyed by his stand "KILLER QUEEN" after defeating KILLER QUEEN's 2nd ability "SHEER HEART ATTACK" and this is where we are shown one of Kira's defening traits: his determantion. through out the entire series we dont see Kira give up and leave Morioh even once and doesnt even consider it. 

This is most obvious in the climax of the first half of the season, where Kira is cornered and is then able to switch his face and blend in back into the crowd. but the man he turned into, Kosaku Kawajiri, had a son, Hayato, which ended up being his demise. but then against all odds, Kira gets stabbed by the Stand arrow again to receive his 3rd and final bomb: BITES THE DUST

a tiny KILLER QUEEN will be placed on a stand-less person and protect them from any harm, BUT should that person talk to anyone about Kira's true identety, KILLER QUEEN will appear in the second persons eye and detonate them. after the detonation, time will reset 1 hour back and whatever happaned last time will be fate unless BITES THE DUST is turned off by Kira. the thing is, the person BITES THE DUST was placed on was hayato who had found out Kira's new identedy, and ended up being murdered by kira the night he gained the ability. this leads into a time loop of Hayato thinking of new ways to defeat Kira with the 4th attemp being succecfull and ended with the best characetr the series has to offer: AMBULANCE-SAN


tl;dr PART 4 IS THE BEST PART IN EVERY ASPECT

I could picture Araki Hirohiko at the end of the third part of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure hurdled up in a chair and thinking about his other random ideas buzzing into his head, as if they were telling him that the Joestar family isn't done showing off yet. But what else could he tell about this story? The climax has been already reached in Stardust Crusaders, with DIO being finally defeated and the survivors getting back home. Dead end.
I could actually picture him walking through his town, asking himself "what if...?". What if we replace the standard shounen antagonist with someone we simply see in thecrowd. No special charisma, no flashy clothing, nothing that could ever drag your attention to him. What if, instead of the world ending threat that has been present in JoJo up to this point, you get to see a silent city with deep scars taking its revenge on the crimes that a certain nobody has committed? What if, instead of those friendships that form between people in need, we see just a group of friends that get through some hardships, but really enjoy themselves and want to spend time with each other, be it chasing a serial killer or hanging in a cafe.


You get a hell of a series.


"Diamond is Unbreakable" is, in my opinion, the best part of JoJo up to this point. It was successful where the other parts failed, and it is so satisfying to see Araki grow as both a better drawing artist and story crafter. 


The animation of this part happens to be inferior to the other three parts, but it makes up for it by using an eyecandy of a color palette. Seriously, the colors were so bright and beautiful in this series that I didn't care about how weird Jotaro looked. I could understand why David Production had a hard time animating this part of the manga, because it was a crucial point for Araki too. Was he ready to give up way too massive for their age boys for the ones that had a realistic body that wasn't 90% up of muscles? He tried. And he was successful, because from this part onward, JoJos look fucking human, not just like a walking mountain with (arguably) personality.


But god, in terms of storytelling, it is far superior. One thing that I loved about DiU is that it doesn't feel like it's Josuke's story. Or Koichi's. Or Okuyasu's. Or Rohan's. It's Morioh's story. Over the course of thee 39 episodes, I enjoyed seeing a group of friends having fun, chasing a villain, encountering an alien, things like that. Yet, I have never felt that the focus was on Josuke especially, even though he is the JoJo of this part. He got to shine as a crazy diamond, and those moments are blissful. But Josuke was designed to be a teenager, and so he is. He doesn't have the care of a primordial being destroying the world or an immortal vampire that is after his family. Seeing a JoJo acting like a teenager is somehow relieving.


The supporting cast of this part is well rounded as well. It's not like every character is just a tool or a motivation for the protagonist to pursue the villain and defeat it. Heck, the villain doesn't even show himself during the first half of the series, letting us get immersed in this town's life before introducing the villain.  I really loved every character, especially Josuke, Rohan and Yoshikage Kira, and generally felt more attached to this cast than the one of Stardust Crusaders or Battle Tendencies or Phantom Blood. The fights got even better, because a considerable part of them weren't just show offs of physical power, but battle of wits. You could expect anything from this battles, and it every fight is memorable and interesting.


One theme that is recurrent in this part is fate and fighting against it. During the second half of the story, it all becomes a fight against fate. Kira Yoshikage has been constantly carrying a fight against his fate as a serial killer. All that time, he just wanted to blend into the background and fade away, living a peaceful life while killing women for their beautiful hands. And when fate finally catches up on him, he is struggling to escape it, and he is not the only one. 


In conclusion, the fourth part of this masterpiece definitely deserves a shot, as it is well rounded, interesting and engaging. It presents us with a large cast of magnificent characters, that are sure to give the audience a good time.

Well, I really don't have anything to say to this anime beyond that it was F***ING AMAZING!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! The story was excellent, sprinkled with short arcs to make the anime a bit more realistic, unlike shows that sprinkle in filler just for filler reasons and lengthening the series for more revenue. *cough* *cough* DBS *cough* *cough* Each episode plays into the eventual conclusion of the show, and the pacing and development is EXCELLENT!!!!! I liked the concept of stands, all of them were unique and fleshed out, unlike a lot of other anime. *cough* *cough* Dragon Ball Super *cough* *cough*. The music was great, Crazy NoisyBizarre Town being one of my all time favorite openings. The characters were excellently designed and were mostly likeable. *Cough* *Cough* Vegeta *Cough*Cough*. Overall, the entire concept of JoJo's is the best of its time, and the modern adaptions augment the already masterful writing.\n
Story: 9, realistic and easy to relate to, excellent\n
Art: 10, unique and colorful, Outsanding\n
Sound: 10, the music is great, and the animation in the OP furthers the excellence of the OPs\n
Characters: 9, colorful and unique, all well fleshed out and likeable\n
Enjoyment: 10, ARE YOU F*****ING KIDDING ME?! IT'S AWESOME!!!!\n
Overall: 8, had some downsides, but still a masterpiece nonetheless.\n
(P.S. Reading this review a few months later and this review is absolute cringe)

I really loved this season, better then crusaders in some way, both are good, but the characters are more relatable.   I'm really glad I watched this, and look forward to hopefully another season soon.
Story:   A simpler story then the last, a town where people are getting powers, are they friends, or foes.   And it works, many creative stands this time around, and thing are far more grey, then the black and white they were in the last season.
Art:   I like the art style, but might be midly offputting to some as it's not as heavily realistic asthe last one, more stylized, best way I can think to describe it is, it almost makes me think of shows like rugrats.\n\n
Characters:   This is where the show really is strong, villians and friends are multi dimensional and not everything is clear cut, the stands are more diverse and unique also.  requiring not always just flat out combat to defeat.\n\n
Enjoyment and overall:   I really liked it, it was well done and sets so many things up wonderfully I feel.

Diamond is Unbreakable is a dramatic departure from the Jojo series.  Instead of a world hopping adventure, it's focused in the small town of Morioh.  Instead of gigantic muscular warriors, it's high school kids.  Instead of having the fate of the world on the line, the cast is trying to stop a serial killer.  It's completely different in almost every way, and while some of it is good, some of it is not so good. 
The not-so-good aspect has to be the change in animation.  The new style, while more modern, loses the vintage 80's feel of the character designfrom earlier series, which I liked and really made Jojo stand out.  Now, if you're going to change it, at least let it be dynamic, but it was really kind of mediocre.  And man, did Jojo's hat blending into his hair look bad.  I guess it's drawn that way in the manga?  But, it looked so cheap and distracting.  


The story also didn't feel as grand or as crazy as Stardust Crusaders.  It felt small.  This is because it stayed in just one small town instead of traversing all over Europe or the Middle East.  That really hurt it, as well.  Really, this felt more like a "Regular" anime, than the kind of unique experience you get from JBA.  I felt like they tried to keep that unique feel, but in doing so, the attempt was somewhat sloppy.  For example: The space alien.  Why? Why was he actually there? What was his purpose? It felt like it was just thrown in because it was "bizarre".  But, it didn't make much sense.  Several things were like that.  Things just happening because it was weird.  


However, what offset this somewhat diminished return of Diamond was the cast.  Once again, Jojo delivers another likable Jojo in Josuke.  (It's kind of incredible how Akira manages to make four great protagonists, when most mangaka struggle with making one.).  Josuke is more like Joesph mixed with Johnathan.  He's mischievous and clever, but also honorable.  But, this cast was stronger than normal, as usually only one guy stands out next to a Joestar, like Speedwagon with Jonathan, or Polnareff with Jotaro and Joseph.  But, this time, the supporting cast was more likeable and memorable over all, with Okuyasu, Koichi and Rohan all being solid characters.  They weren't as great as someone like Jean Pierre Polnareff, but they weren't as forgettable as Kakyouin, either.  


On the flip side of that, the villains weren't very impressive.  It really seemed like they were running out of ideas for weird villain powers, so we ended up with people who played Rock, Paper, Scissors as a power, and the Transmission tower guy.  People who, for no reason whatsoever, decided they would stand against Josuke and crew.  That's one of the big logic flaws of this anime:  (SPOILER AHEAD)  There was no logical reason for all these people to be fighting for Kira's dad.  With Dio, his followers made sense, because he was using flesh buds to control them and he was so insanely powerful, they were afraid to oppose him.  But, for what reason did these citizens decide they would side with a serial killer's dad?  The arrow gave them stands, it didn't control their minds.  There was no reason for them to fight to protect the identity of Kira or try to kill Jotaro and crew.  They were just doing it to do it, outside of Angelo.  


At the very least, however, Kira was a good villain.  In fact, the ONLY good villain.  So, fortunately, he was the main antagonist.  He reminded me a good deal of Hiro from Inuyashiki, but more bizarre.  A careful and compulsive killer, some of his moments were the most suspenseful in the anime. The anime really picked up once the Heroes caught wind of him and started to try and track him down.  


Overall, this is a pretty good anime.  But, that's it, just "good", not "classic" like the other installments.  And that makes it somewhat of a disappointment.  If this was some other franchise, I would be satisfied with it being good.  But, with this being Jojo, I expect excellence.  As I jump into Golden Wind, hopefully it will get back up to the standards put out by the previous installments.


Story: 7

Art: 5

Sound: 7

Character: 10

Enjoyment: 8

Overall: 8
